factoid: Natásha said "I will".
Natásha's face suddenly flushed with reckless and joyous resolution.
Natásha half rose.
Natásha gave Pierre a glance inviting him to listen to what was coming.
Natásha turned to her mother.
Natásha's childish voice rang out "Mamma!" with clear contralto notes audible the whole length of the table.
The countess asked "What is it?".
The countess saw that Natásha's face indicated mischief.
The countess shook a finger at Natásha sternly with a threatening and forbidding movement of her head.
The conversation became hushed.
Natásha asked "Mamma! What sweets are we going to have?".
Natásha's voice sounded firm and resolute.
The countess tried to frown but could not.
Márya Dmítrievna shook her fat finger.
Márya Dmítrievna said "Cossack!" threateningly.
Most guests looked at the elders uncertain how to regard this sally.
The countess said "You had better take care!".
Natásha again cried "Mamma! What sweets are we going to have?".
Natásha cried boldly with saucy gaiety.
Natásha was confident that her prank would be taken in good part.
Sónya and fat little Pétya doubled up with laughter.
Natásha whispered "You see! I have asked" to her little brother and to Pierre.
Natásha glanced at Pierre again.
Márya Dmítrievna said "Ice pudding, but you won't get any.".
Natásha saw there was nothing to be afraid of.
Natásha braved Márya Dmítrievna.
Natásha said "Márya Dmítrievna! What kind of ice pudding? I don't like ice cream.".
Márya Dmítrievna replied "Carrot ices.".
Natásha almost screamed "No! What kind, Márya Dmítrievna? What kind?".
Natásha said "I want to know!".
Márya Dmítrievna and the countess burst out laughing.
All guests joined in.
Everyone laughed at the incredible boldness and smartness of Natásha who dared to treat Márya Dmítrievna in this fashion.
Natásha desisted when she was told that there would be pineapple ice.
Before the ices, champagne was served round.
The band struck up again.
The count and countess kissed.
The guests left their seats and went up to "congratulate" the countess.
The guests reached across the table to clink glasses with the count.
The guests reached across the table to clink glasses with the children.
The guests reached across the table to clink glasses with one another.
The footmen rushed about again.
Chairs scraped.
The guests returned to the drawing room and to the count's study in the same order in which they had entered but with redder faces.
The card tables were drawn out.
Sets were made up for boston.
The count's visitors settled themselves.
Some visitors settled in the two drawing rooms.
Some visitors settled in the sitting room.
Some visitors settled in the library.
The count held his cards fanwise.
The count kept himself with difficulty from dropping into his usual after-dinner nap.
The count laughed at everything.
The young people gathered round the clavichord and harp at the countess' instigation.
Julie by general request played first.
Julie played a little air with variations on the harp.
Julie joined the other young ladies in begging Natásha and Nicholas to sing something.
Natásha and Nicholas were noted for their musical talent.
Natásha was treated as though she were grown up.
Natásha was evidently very proud of this.
Natásha felt shy.
Natásha said "What shall we sing?".
Nicholas suggested "The Brook.".
Natásha said "Well, then, let's be quick. Borís, come here.".
Natásha asked "But where is Sónya?".
Natásha looked round.
Natásha saw her friend was not in the room.
Natásha ran to look for her.
Natásha ran into Sónya's room and did not find her there.
Natásha ran to the nursery.
Sónya was not there.
Natásha concluded that Sónya must be on the chest in the passage.
The chest in the passage was the place of mourning for the younger female generation in the Rostóv household.
Sónya was lying face downward on Nurse’s dirty feather bed on the top of the chest.
Sónya crumpled her gauzy pink dress under her.
Sónya hid her face with her slender fingers.
Sónya sobbed so convulsively that her bare little shoulders shook.
Natásha's face had been radiantly happy all that saint's day.
Natásha's face suddenly changed.
Natásha's eyes became fixed.
A shiver passed down Natásha's broad neck.
The corners of Natásha's mouth drooped.
